<p>A few weeks ago I did a short talk on <a href="http://yeoman.io">Yeoman</a> at the Linzer edition of <a href="http://codeweek.eu">Codeweek</a> and how it helps us in our daily workflow. For the first time I tried to have some sort of script, and afterwards I even made notes. So aside from funny images, you even can read what I was talking about. Have fun!</p> <div class="aspect ratio-4-to-3"> <iframe class="speakerdeck-iframe" frameborder="0" src="//speakerdeck.com/player/35abc1f061d00132d663726ecad34358?" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe> </div> <p><a href="https://speakerdeck.com/ddprrt/a-short-introduction-to-yeoman">Find the slides on speakerdeck</a></p> <ol> <li>I don’t know if you’ve ever heard from Yeoman or the Yeoman tools.</li> <li>It might actually be that you’ve heard from the Yeoman warders who guard the tower of London. They’re also called beefeaters and might happen to have a strong taste for gin</li> <li>They even have their own brand, which tastes great btw.</li> <li>Anyhow, the Yeoman warders at the Tower of London are helpful guides and show you around on your sightseeing tour. This helpfulness inspired a bunch of software developers like Addy Osmani to create a not less helpful tool or toolchain to guide you in your software development process. And Yeoman, or not be precise, Yo, is the result.</li> <li>We’re using Yo to overcome a lot of obstacles in our day-to-day workflow. This is Pinky, my colleague and the guy I work with most of the time. The other one is a random “Brain” from our team.</li> <li>We happen to do a lot of new projects, mostly microsites, and have the need to kick-start a new project often on a weekly base. So, if we try to get a new project running, every developer has his own way of doing so.</li> <li>While Pinky might call his folders like the technology he is using,</li> <li>Our random brain might call it after the actual type: Styles, scripts and templates.</li> <li>If you have one generic build running, like Grunt, you can adapt this very Gruntfile for each solution.</li> <li>This was even worse when we used a 1500 lines of code Ant File</li> <li>which looked like this (Animation)</li> <li>And this was my face when my co-workers asked me to change the build to their new setup. Every single time.</li> <li>This is where our Yeomen come in.</li> <li>First it give’s me the much needed Gin,</li> <li>but actually they’re helping me to settle on a good set of defaults and best practices, and provide a way to distribute them to everybody in my team.</li> <li>They’re doing this by so-called generators. Each generator is used for a different eco-system. You even can develop a generator to create a custom project setup for your very own team.</li> <li>It also helps to overcome the blank page angst. You don’t have to start from scratch and actually have a good setup where you can easily add your new parts. This helped me a lot when starting with Angular, because there were a lot of repetitive patterns which I couldn’t memorise at first.</li> <li>Yo is based on node.js, so it is easily installed with NPM. The second command installs a generator. This is one provided by the Yeoman community, which is strongly supported by Google. That’s one reason why they have a nifty Angular generator ready. To kickstart a new Angular project, just run <code>yo angular</code> in your project folder. Yo will find yourself in a short questionnaire to set some options and parameters, after that Yeoman takes care of the rest. They’re also some subgenerators possible. In this case, I can add a new directive to an existing Angular project. Let’s try this out (demo)</li> <li>If you’re not happy with the community generator, it’s easy to create your own. Yo has even a generator for generators, which gives you the very basic setup. After that, you just have four commands which you really need to finish your generator.</li> <li><code>this.prompt()</code> sets up the questionnaire and sets some variables. With <code>this.dest.mkdir()</code> you’re creating new directories, <code>this.src.copy()</code> copies files from your generators template directory to the desired destination, and <code>this.src.template()</code> does the same, but allows form parametrised output using underscore templates.</li> <li>At the moment there are about 1100 generators available</li> <li>Even our own one which is open source. Feel free to learn from it, we sure did a lot.</li> <li>With this generator we managed to setup one project structure easily every time we need it.</li> <li>I have a lot more time for Gin now</li> <li>And also a much happier face. Thank you.</li> </ol> <p>Image credits: <a href="http://www.yeoman.io">Yeoman</a></p>
